ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Ras1 and Ras2 homology, expression and protein localization.

In red (Ras1) and blue (Ras2) are shaded identical amino acids. GTP Binding domains are indicated by green boxes (G1, amino

acids 10–18; G2, amino acids 57–63; G3, amino acids 116–119 and G4 amino acids 143–146); effector binding domain (amino acids 32–40) is in red box; switch I (amino acids 25–40) and switch II (amino acids 60–76), corresponding GAP and GEF binding domains, are indicated by white arrows. The CAAX motif is indicated in a blue box. (B–C) Expression in the wing disc of anti-sense (B) and sense (C) probes for Ras1. (D–E) Expression in the wing disc of anti-sense (B) and sense (C) probes for Ras2. Molecular and phenotypic characterization of Ras2 mutant alleles.

Wing phenotypes and expression of dP-Erk and P-Akt in wing discs expressing activated Ras1 and Ras2 and other mutations in the EGFR and InR pathways.

ja:head.ce:title: Ras2, the TC21/R-Ras2 Drosophila homologue, contributes to insulin signalling but is not required for organism viability

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Ras1 (Ras85D) and Ras2 (Ras64B) are the Drosophila orthologs of human H-Ras/N-Ras/K-Ras and R-Ras1-3 genes, respectively. The function of Ras1 has been thoroughly characterised during Drosophila embryonic and imaginal development, and it is associated with coupling activated trans-membrane receptors with tyrosine kinase activity to their downstream effectors. In this capacity, Ras1 binds and is required for the activation of Raf. Ras1 can also interact with PI3K, and it is needed to achieve maximal levels of PI3K signalling in specific cellular settings. In contrast, the function of the unique Drosophila R-Ras member (Ras2/Ras64B), which is more closely related to vertebrate R-Ras2/TC21, has been only studied through the use of constitutively activated forms of the protein. This pioneering work identified a variety of phenotypes that were related to those displayed by Ras1, suggesting that Ras1 and Ras2 might have overlapping activities. Here we find that Ras2 can interact with PI3K and Raf and activate their downstream effectors Akt and Erk. However, and in contrast to mutants in Ras1, which are lethal, null alleles of Ras2 are viable in homozygosis and only show a phenotype of reduced wing size and extended life span that might be related to reduced Insulin receptor signalling.

ce:list-item.ce:para: We generated mutations in the Drosophila Ras2 gene, orthologous to human RRas1, RRas2/TC21 and RRas3.
Loss of Ras2 function does not compromise organism viability, but cause reduced wing size and expanded life span.
Ras2 interact with the InR transducer PI3K.
Activated and overexpressed Ras2 can supply for Ras1 function.
Ras2 participates in one of several complementary mechanisms downstream to InR.

ce:section.ce:para: Signalling by tyrosine kinase transmembrane receptors involves the assembling of protein complexes in their cytoplasmic tails that connect the receptor with downstream effectors (Simanshu et al., 2017). Among the most prominent components of these complexes are guanine nucleotide-binding proteins of the Ras superfamily, which can cycle between active GTP- and inactive GDP-bound states. The cycling of typical Ras superfamily members is controlled by proteins that promote the exchange of GDP for GTP (Guanine nucleotide Exchange Factors or GEFs), and by proteins that enhance the Ras GTPase activity (GTPase Activating Proteins or GAPs) (Bernards, 2003). Other adaptor proteins interact with receptor phospho-tyrosines, and bring GEFs to the cell membrane, where they trigger Ras activation and allow Ras-GTP to interact with cytoplasmic targets (Bernards, 2003). Classical Ras subfamily proteins in humans include H-Ras, N-Ras and K-Ras. These proteins present a 90–100% conserved amino-terminal catalytic domain of 165 amino acids and a less conserved carboxy-terminal stretch of 25 amino acids, named hypervariable region (HVR) that is important for posttranscriptional modifications and subcellular localization (Simanshu et al., 2017). Direct effectors of Ras-GTP are the Raf kinases, leading to activation of the MAP kinase cascade, and phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase (PI3K), which contributes to the stimulation of Akt (Simanshu et al., 2017). Interestingly, and despite the overall sequence conservation present between classic Ras members, K-Ras is the more potent activator of Raf-1, and H-Ras the more potent activator of PI3K (Voice et al., 1999). Furthermore K-Ras-knockout mice are embryonic lethal, whereas H-Ras, N-Ras and H-Ras–N-Ras double knockouts survive normally (Esteban et al., 2001; Koera et al., 1997). Some of the differences in the behaviour of Ras genes rely on the regulation of each gene expression, because, for example, H-Ras expression from the K-Ras locus is able to rescue the lethality of K-Ras knockout mice (Potenza et al., 2005).

The Ras-related protein subfamily (R-Ras) includes R-Ras1, R-Ras2 (TC21) and R-Ras3 (M-Ras). These proteins have similar size and display overall sequence conservation (63%) with classical Ras (Graham et al., 1994). They can also activate the same downstream effectors with different efficiency. R-Ras2/TC21, in addition, displays a transforming activity similar to that of K-Ras (Graham et al., 1994), and stimulates the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinases, PI3K, Ral signalling and transcription from Ras-responsive promoters (Movilla et al., 1999; Ohba et al., 2000; Rosario et al., 1999, 2001). R-Ras2/TC21 is particularly required in vivo for the survival of mature T- and B-cells populations, and interacts with different subunits of the T-cell and B-cell antigen receptors (Delgado et al., 2009). In these cellular settings, R-Ras2/TC21 contributes to the maintenance of housekeeping levels of PI3K activity (Delgado et al., 2009; Larive et al., 2012). Therefore, R-Ras2/TC21 appears more specialized in the activation of the PI3K pathway rather than the Raf/ERK one (Larive et al., 2012). The distinction between classical Ras and R-Ras subfamilies is already present in insects. Thus, in Drosophila melanogaster there is one member of each subfamily: Ras1 (Ras85D) is related to classical Ras, whereas Ras2 (Ras64B) is more similar to R-Ras2/TC21. Ras1 plays a central role in the EGFR-Raf-Erk signalling cascade (Diaz-Benjumea and Hafen, 1994; Simon et al., 1991), but is also required in specific developmental contexts to promote maximal PI(3)K signalling (Orme et al., 2006).

The analysis of Ras1 and Ras2 has relied to some extent on the use of activating mutations that render these proteins insensitive to GAPs. These mutations, G12V in Ras1 and G14V in Ras2, are strongly oncogenic in humans, and cause a variety of developmental effects during Drosophila embryonic and imaginal development (Bishop and Corces, 1988; Rajalingam et al., 2007). Further genetic analysis in this organism identified Ras1 requirements to regulate cell growth (Heumann et al., 2000; Prober and Edgar, 2000), the progression through the G1/S transition of the cell cycle (Johnston et al., 1999; Prober and Edgar, 2002; Weinkove et al., 1999) and cell fate and territorial specification (Guichard et al., 1999; Simon et al., 1991; Wang et al., 2000; Zecca and Struhl, 2002). These effects are mediated by Ras1 acting as a core component of the EGFR and other tyrosine kinase transmembrane receptors, ultimately stimulating the Raf/MEK/ERK signalling cascade. Less clear is the relationships between Ras1 and the Insulin receptor (InR) signalling pathway, which is required in imaginal cells for growth and acts activating the PI3K/Akt/Tor signalling cascade (Lizcano and Alessi, 2002; Oldham and Hafen, 2003). In imaginal discs, the epithelia that give rise to the adult structures of the fly, activated forms of Ras1 promote growth acting through the dPI3K pathway and dMyc (Prober and Edgar, 2002), in a similar manner as its vertebrate counterparts in mammalian cell cultures (Pacold et al., 2000; Sears et al., 2000). However, endogenous Ras1 is only required to maintain normal levels of dMyc (Prober and Edgar, 2002), and Ras mediated activation of PI3K is only essential during germ cell development and to acquire maximal levels of PI3K signalling (Orme et al., 2006). To date, no specific function has been assigned to Ras2, although its constitutive activation affects processes regulated by the EGFR pathway such as vein formation in the wing and cell fate specification in the eye (Bishop and Corces, 1988; Strutt and Strutt, 2003).

Here we present a genetic and developmental analysis of Ras2, focussing on its requirements during the development of the wing imaginal disc. We have generated a collection of Ras2 mutant alleles via CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing. We show that the function of Ras2 is not required for organism viability, and that loss of Ras2 has no significant effects on diphospho-ERK (dP-ERK) accumulation. Instead, Ras2 mutants show reduced wing size, extended lifespan and reduced overall levels of P-Akt. We also show that Ras2 interacts with PI3K and to a lesser extent with Raf, suggesting that this protein has retained the ability to engage in similar interactions to Ras1, but that these interactions are not operative at physiological levels of expression or are masked by Ras1 function. In contrast, activated Ras2 can substitute for Ras1 function when overexpressed, further suggesting that overexpression and hyperactivation minimizes the functional divergence of Ras1 and Ras2 towards a common set of downstream effectors.

We used the following Gal4 lines salEPv-Gal4 (Cruz et al., 2009), nub-Gal4, hh-Gal4 and en-Gal4 (Calleja et al., 1996). We also used from Bloomington stock center the stocks phm-Gal4 (BL26159), UAS-EGFRDN (BL5634), UAS-EGFRlTop (BL 59843), UAS-InRact (BL8263), UAS-InRDN (BL8263) and UAS-GFP. We generated the following UAS lines: UAS-Raf-Myc, UAS-Flag-Ras1, UAS-Flag-Ras1V12, UAS-Flag-Ras2, UAS-Flag-Ras2V14 and UAS-Dp110-Myc. We also used the following RNA interference lines UAS-Ras1-i (28129), UAS-PTEN-i (35731) and UAS-dp110-i (107390) from the VDRC Stock Center. Flies were raised at 25 ​°C unless otherwise stated.

We analysed at least 10 wings from females of each genotype. Cell size was estimated from the number of trichomes in a dorsal region located between the L3 and L4 veins and wing size was measured in pixels, in both cases using the Analyse tool in Adobe Photoshop. Wing pictures were made with a Spot digital camera coupled to a Zeiss Axiplam microscope using the 5X and 40X objectives for wing sizes and trichome number, respectively. For all combinations analysed the pictures shown in the figures are representative of the resulting phenotype. Wing size measures of genetic combinations shown in Figs. 2 and 7 are presented in Supple. Fig. 1A and B. We only measured wings without major folding, as wing folding interferes with wing physical size.

ce:section.ce:section-title: P-Akt measurement in imaginal wing discs
ce:section.ce:para: P-Akt levels of expression in wing discs from Figs. 6 and 7 were quantified using the tool “Analyse” from Phothoshop CS3 or ImageJ 1.48u (NIH, USA). We measured the “average grey value” in four pairs of squares located within and without the domain of salEPv-Gal4 or hh-Gal4 expression in the wing blade. We use at least ten independent discs.

All numerical data including western blots, wing size, cell size and number, and intensity values were collected and processed in Microsoft Excel (t-test) and Prism 6 (survival curves comparisons) (Microsoft Inc.) and data were compared using a T-test. The statistical analyses of survival curves were carried out using Log-rank (Mantel-Cox) and Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon tests. Graphic representations were done with Prism 6. Box plots show the median and the first and third quartiles. Column bar graphs show mean with standard deviation. Unless otherwise indicated, we analysed at least 10 wing imaginal discs or mutant wings for each antibody staining and genetic combination. We consider that there is a significant difference when the p-value is lower than 0.001 (***), 0.01 (**) or 0.05 (*).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Generation of Raf, PI3K, Ras1 and Ras2 constructs
ce:section.ce:para: The following constructs were generated: UAS-Raf-Myc, UAS-dp110-Myc, UAS-Flag-Ras1, UAS-Flag-Ras1V12, UAS-Flag-Ras2, UAS-Flag-Ras2V14, GST-Ras2, and GST-Ras2V14. Transgenic flies were generated by germ line injection in y w embryos following standard procedures (Rubin and Spradling, 1982). For each construct we generated at least three independent insertions. The coding sequence of each gene was obtained by PCR amplification of the following plasmids: EST GH03557 (DGCR) (Raf), EST SD05105 (DGCR) (Dp110), EST RE53955 (DGCR) (Ras1), and EST RE36103 (DGCR) (Ras2) (primers used are detailed in Supple. Table 1). Each PCR product was directionally cloned into pENTR/D-TOPO® (Invitrogen). Mutant versions (Ras1V12 and Ras2V14) were generated with the QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene) using as template Ras1-pENTR/D-TOPO® or Ras2-pENTR/D-TOPO® (see Supple. Table 1). The presence of each mutation was confirmed by sequencing the construct.

For obtaining the C-terminal-Myc-tagged fusion proteins, we used the LR Clonase II® reaction with Raf-pENTR/D-TOPO® or PI3K-pENTR/D-TOPO® and the pTWM (6XMyc-tag at the C-terminal) vector. For generating the N-terminal-Flag-tagged fusion proteins, we used the LR Clonase II® reaction with Ras1-pENTR/D-TOPO®, Ras1V12-pENTR/D-TOPO®, Ras2-pENTR/D-TOPO® or Ras2V14-pENTR/D-TOPO® and the pTFW (3XFlag-tag at the N-terminal) vector. For expression in vivo in Gal4-expressing cells we followed the instructions from Invitrogen. The expression of these tagged proteins in the wing disc is shown in Fig. 6A–H.

For generating GST-Ras2 and GST-Ras2V14 constructs, Ras2-pENTR/TOPO® or Ras2V14-pENTR/TOPO® were used with the Clonase II® and the pDEST™15 vector (Thermo Fisher Scientific) for fusion-protein bacterial expression vector generation.

We used the rabbit antibodies anti-diphosphorylated ERK1&2 and anti-phospho Akt (Cell Signalling). We also used the mouse monoclonal antibodies anti-c-Myc 9E10 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) and anti-FlagM2 (Sigma). Alexa Fluor secondary antibodies (used at 1:200 dilution) were from Invitrogen. Imaginal wing discs were dissected, fixed, and stained as described in [50]. Confocal images were taken in a LSM510 confocal microscope (Zeiss). In situ hybridization with Ras2 and Ras1 probes were carried out as described (de Celis, 1997). We used the cDNA RE36103 as template to synthesize the Ras2 probe. Z-sections were taken from 100 tangential planes of the wing blade region using the 63x objective. All images were processed with the program ImageJ 1.48u (NIH, USA) and Adobe Photoshop CS3.

For CRISPR-Cas9-mediated Ras2 mutagenesis we followed the strategy described in (Kondo and Ueda, 2013). Genomic Ras2 target sites were identified at (http://www.flyrnai.org/crispr2/). Prior to final selection of Ras2 guides, genomic PCR and sequencing of nos-Cas9 flies was performed to check for polymorphisms in the target regions. The 24bp oligonucleotides selected guide RNAs were 5′CTTCCGTGTACGAGTCTTCAATGG3′ and 5′AAACCCATTGAAGACTCGTACACG3’. The presence of mutations was confirmed by sequencing PCR products obtained using genomic DNA from homozygous w; Ras2* flies as template. Stocks w; Ras2* that were no mutant for Ras2 were used as control flies in lifespan, timing and western blots experiments.

The fusion proteins GST-Ras2 and GST-Ras2V14 and the GST protein (negative control) were expressed in E. coli BL21 strain. Following induction with 1 ​mM IPTG, the GST-fusion proteins were purified by chromatography on Glutathione Sepharose 4B according to manufacturer’s instructions (GE Healthcare). 1–3 ​mg of GST or GST fusion proteins were mixed with 25 ​μl of 50% suspension of Glutathione Sepharose 4B for 1h at 4 ​°C in RIPA Buffer (40 ​mM Tris-HCl pH7.5, 120 ​mM NaCl, 1% NP40, 0,5% DOC, 0,1% SDS, 6 EDTA, 6 ​mM EGTA, 10 ​mM NaF, 1 ​mM Na3VO4 and protease inhibitors cocktail from Roche). The purity of purified proteins was made from Coomassie-brillant-blue staining of SDS-polyacrylamide gels and the concentration determined by the Lowry Protein Assay (BioRad DC Protein Assay). In vitro transcription and translation reactions (50 ​μl) for Dp110 and Raf were carried out using an RRL system (TNTT7 Quick Coupled Transcription/Translation System; Promega, Madison, WI) with 1 ​μg of pOT vector containing the cDNA SD05105 (Dp110) or GH03557 (Raf)) incubating for 90 ​min ​at 30 ​°C with 25 ​μCi of [S35]-Met (Amersham). The pull-down assay was performed incubating over-night at 4 ​°C the same amount of GST or GST fusion proteins bound to Glutathione Sepharose 4B with in vitro translated Raf and Dp110. After centrifugation and washes the proteins were resolved by 6% SDS/PAGE and the existence of pull-down proteins was analysed by autoradiography. The pulldown experiments were repeated 3 times with the same results.

Embryos and larvae lysates: Embryos were collected 24 ​h after egg laying, washed in a 0.7% NaCl +0.04% Triton X-100 solution, de-corionated in 50% bleach and freezed at −80 ​°C. Third instar larvae (10 larvae per replicate condition) were collected, washed in cold PBS and freezed at −80 ​°C. Embryos were homogenised in immunoprecipitation (IP) buffer (40 ​mM Tris-HCl, 120 ​mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 0.1% SDS, 0.5% DOC, 6 ​mM EDTA, 6 ​mM EGTA, 100 ​μM PMSF and complete EDTA-free protease inhibitor cocktail tablet (Roche)) and larvae were homogenised with RIPA-CHAPSO buffer (40 ​mM Tris-HCl, 120 ​mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 0.1% SDS, 0.5% DOC, 1% CHAPSO, 6 ​mM EDTA, 6 ​mM EGTA, 10 ​mM NaF, 0,4 ​mM Na₃VO₄·2H₂O, 8 ​μg/ml Aprotinin, 100 ​μM PMSF and 2X HealtTM Protease and Phosphatase Inhibitor Cocktail (Thermo Scientific)). Both embryos and larvae were then incubated 2h at 4 ​°C. Lysates were clarified by centrifugation. Protein concentration in these lysates was determined by Lowry assay (BioRad DC Protein Assay).

Immunoprecipitation: 50 ​μg and 2 ​mg of total protein from embryonic lysates were used to assess protein expression levels (input) and for the immunoprecipitation reactions, respectively. Immunoprecipitation reactions were performed by incubating the lysates with 1 ​mg/ml BSA, 10% Glycerol and specific antibodies for Dp110-Myc (15 ​μl of anti-Myc agarose, Santa Cruz Biotechnology), and for Flag-Ras2 (15 ​μl of anti-FlagM2 agarose, Sigma) in RIPA Buffer at 4 ​°C for 12–16h. The beads were washed three times with RIPA buffer and boiled in Laemmli sample buffer for 10 ​min. The immunoprecipitation experiments for Ras2 and Dp110 were repeated 5 times.

Immunoblotting: Embryo lysates or immunoprecipitated complexes (IP) and larval lysates (Western blot) were resolved by 7.5% SDS-PAGE and proteins were transferred to nitrocellulose membranes using a semi-dry blotting apparatus (BioRad). We used the following primary antibodies: anti-diphospho-ERK (Phospho-p44/42 MAPK (Erk1/2) (Thr202/Tyr204) (D13.14.4E) XP Rabbit mAb #4370 from Cell Signalling used 1:1000), anti-pan-ERK (p44/42 MAPK (Erk1/2) Antibody#9102 from Cell Signalling used 1:500), anti-phospho-Akt (Phospho-Drosophila Akt (Ser505) antibody #4054 from Cell Signalling used 1:1000), anti-pan-Akt (Akt (pan) (C67E7) Rabbit mAb #4691 from Cell Signalling used 1:500) and anti-gamma-tubulin (1:1000) (Sigma); Dp110-Myc protein was detected by incubating with anti-Myc monoclonal antibody (1:200) (c-Myc 9E10, Santa Cruz Biotechnology). Ras2-Flag proteins were detected by incubating with anti-Flag polyclonal antibody (1:1000) (Thermo Scientific). Immunoblots were developed using IR680 and 800 labelled antibodies (Li-Cor) with the Odyssey Infrared Imaging System (Li-Cor) and/or ECL™ peroxidase-labelled anti-mouse or anti-rabbit antibodies revealed with ECL Western Blotting Detection Reagents (GE Healthcare). Western blots for determining di-phospho-ERK and phosphor-Akt amount were repeated 5 times.

For lifespan experiments newly eclosed flies were collected and kept at a density of 15–20 males per vial on standard conditions. Flies were transferred to new vials twice per week. Total flies used were n ​= ​96 for control flies (w; Ras2+), n ​= ​79 for Ras23 mutant and n ​= ​136 for Ras217 mutant (w; Ras2mut). Control flies for Ras2 alleles were from a w; Ras2+ strain obtained using the same crosses as the strains carrying mutations in Ras2.

For calculating developmental timing we measured the time in days from egg laying to puparium formation. We used 3-days old flies (5 males and 10 females per vial) that were transferred daily to a new vial. The number of pupae was counted each 24 ​h. At least 100 pupae were counted per genotype. All life span and developmental timing experiments were conducted at 25 ​°C in flies of the same genetic background. Control flies for Ras2 alleles was a w; Ras2+ strain obtained using the same crosses as the strains carrying mutations in Ras2.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Wing phenotypes of activating mutations in Ras1 and Ras2
ce:section.ce:para: Drosophila Ras1 and Ras2 are very similar proteins in sequence, but can be grouped by sequence conservation with true Ras and with Ras-related human counterparts, respectively (Fig. 1A; see (Jancik et al., 2010) for a description of Ras functional domains). Both Ras genes are expressed in a generalised manner in the wing disc, the epithelial tissue that gives rise to the adult wing and thorax of the fly (Fig. 1B–E). To visualize the subcellular localization of Ras1 and Ras2, we expressed tagged versions of the proteins in the Ring Gland, a tissue formed by cells much larger than imaginal cells, and observed that normal and activated Ras1 (Ras1V12) and Ras2 (Ras2V14) proteins accumulate in close association with the cell membrane (Fig. 1F–I). The overexpression of activated forms of Ras1 and Ras2 in the wing results in similar but not identical phenotypes. Thus, all Gal4/UAS combinations involving Ras1V12 show varying degrees of ectopic vein formation (stronger at higher transgene copy number and temperature; Fig. 2B and see below), wing folding and in some cases slightly larger wing size (Supple. Fig. 1). In the case of Ras2V14 overexpression, we also found larger wing size (Supple. Fig. 1), ectopic veins and also defects in epithelial integrity, revealed by the formation of balls of wing tissue that are trapped between the dorsal and ventral wing surfaces (Fig. 2C). Ectopic vein formation and defects in epithelial integrity are stronger when Ras1V12 and Ras2V14 overexpression is combined (Fig. 2D), which is compatible with a dose effect of higher levels of activated-Ras expression (Ras1v12/Ras2v14). Knockdown of Ras1 results in smaller than normal wings that fail to differentiate the veins (Fig. 2E and Supple. Fig. 1A). Interestingly, activated Ras2 totally suppresses the Ras1 loss-of-function phenotype (Fig. 2F and Supple. Fig. 1A), suggesting that Ras2 constitutively activated and overexpressed can substitute for Ras1 function. In summary, the analysis of Ras1 and Ras2 activating mutations suggests that both proteins affect a similar set of target genes with different efficiency when overexpressed.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Generation and analysis of Ras2 mutants
ce:section.ce:para: To identify the normal requirements of Ras2 during development, we generated a set of Ras2 loss of function alleles using CRISPR-Cas9 (see material and methods). We selected several frame-shift alleles causing premature stop codons (Ras21, Ras23, Ras212 and Ras211; Fig. 3A) and two internal deletions of 5 and 7 amino acids (Ras210 and Ras217, respectively; Fig. 3A). We focused our analysis on Ras23, a null allele, and Ras217, a deletion of 7 amino acids located in the switch I region of Ras2, a domain required for its interaction with GAP proteins and downstream effectors (Castellano and Santos, 2011; Jancik et al., 2010). Flies homozygous for these alleles are viable and fertile, indicating that Ras2 is not required for general viability. In both cases we observe a moderate reduction in wing size (7,6% and 9,4% for Ras23 and Ras217, respectively; Fig. 3B–D and E) mostly caused by lower number of cells (Fig. 3F and G). Interestingly, and in contrast to Ras1 loss-of-function conditions, Ras2 mutants do not affect vein formation (Figs. 2E and Fig. 3B–D). To further explore the consequences of Ras2 loss, we measured developmental timing and life span in Ras2 mutants and control flies. We found that Ras2 mutants have delayed pupariation (Fig. 3H) and extended life span in normal growth media (Fig. 3I). This last phenotype is stronger in Ras217 flies, perhaps because this mutant might interact with upstream activators, but not with downstream effectors, and consequently could display a dominant-negative effect on Ras activity. Extended life span is also caused by lower than normal levels of Ras1 in specific tissues (Slack et al., 2015).

We wondered whether the mild phenotypes caused by loss of Ras2 might be due to compensation by Ras1 activity. To analyse this possibility, we reduced Ras1 expression in a Ras2 mutant background (Fig. 4A and B). We found that loss of Ras2 increases the phenotype of smaller wing size and cell size caused by reduced expression of Ras1 (Fig. 4C–E), suggesting some degree of functional similarity between Ras1 and Ras2 in this experimental setting.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effects of Ras1 and Ras2 activation on InR and EGFR signalling
ce:section.ce:para: Ras proteins function downstream of activated tyrosine kinase transmembrane receptors such as InR and EGFR. The activation of EGFR leads to the phosphorylation in Ser/Thr and Tyr residues of the MAP kinase ERK. In the wing pouch region of the wing disc phosphorylated ERK (dP-ERK) is mostly accumulated in the developing longitudinal veins and in two stripes of cells abutting the wing margin (Gabay et al., 1997, Fig. 5A-A′). As expected, expression of activated EGFR increases dP-ERK accumulation (Fig. 5B-B′), whereas expression of RNAi against ERK reduces dP-ERK (Fig. 5C-C′). Overexpression of Ras1V12 (Fig. 5D-D′) and Ras2V14 (Fig. 5E-E′) increase ERK phosphorylation, and this effect is stronger in the case of Ras1V12 (compare Fig. 5 D′ and E’).

We used Akt phosphorylation as reporter of InR activation in Ras2 mutant larvae and in imaginal discs bearing Ras1 and Ras2 activating mutations. First we measured the levels of total Akt and P-Akt in protein extracts from Ras2 mutant larvae We found a weak but significant reduction in the level of P-Akt in Ras217 larvae (28%; Fig. 5F and G). In the case of Ras23 we also found a weak reduction in P-Akt (16%) that was not statistically significant (Fig. 5F and G). The different quantitative effect of Ras23 and Ras217 is likely due to a Ras217 mutant protein dominant negative effect, as also observed in lifespan experiments. A systemic reduction of P-Akt in mutant Ras2 larvae is compatible with a requirement of Ras2 to reach normal levels of InR activity. We also measure total Erk and dP-Erk in Ras23 and Ras217 mutant larvae, but we did not detect a significant difference in the levels of dP-Erk comparing Ras2 mutant larvae to controls (Fig. 5F and G).

P-Akt is detected in the cytoplasm of all wing imaginal disc cells at similar levels (Fig. 6A-A′ and I). We could not detect obvious changes in P-Akt accumulation when either Ras1V12 (Fig. 6B-B’and I) or Ras2V14 (Fig. 6C-C″ and I) are overexpressed in the central region of the wing blade. In contrast, and as expected, the expression of activated forms of the InR results in a strong increase in the accumulation of P-Akt (Fig. 6F-F′ and I; Supple. Fig. 1C), and the expression of Akt-RNAi leads to a strong depletion of P-Akt (Fig. 6H-Hi, I and Supple. Fig. 1C). The reduction of PTEN expression in the central domain of the wing disc also causes a significant increase in the accumulation of P-AKT (Fig. 6G-G′ and I). We also expressed and analysed P-Akt accumulation upon stronger expression of Ras1V12 and Ras2V14 in the posterior compartment using the hh-Gal4 driver (Fig. 6D–E and L). In these genetic backgrounds (UAS-Ras1V12/ ​+ ​; hh-Gal4 UAS-GFP/ ​+ ​; Fig. 6D-D´´´and UAS-Ras2V14/ ​+ ​; hh-Gal4 UAS-GFP/ ​+ ​; Fig. 6E-E´´´) we could detect a significant increase in the accumulation of P-Akt in posterior compartments expressing Ras1V12 or Ras2V14 versus the anterior ones (Fig. 6J). These results indicate that only high levels of Ras1V12 or Ras2V14 are effective in promoting P-Akt phosphorylation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Functional relationships between Ras proteins and insulin receptor/EGFR signalling
ce:section.ce:para: The phenotypes observed in Ras2 mutant flies and its requirement to achieve normal levels of Akt phosphorylation are compatible with a weak and generalised reduction in InR signalling in Ras2 mutant cells (Broughton et al., 2005; Haselton et al., 2010). However, even moderate changes of InR activity in the wing disc result in stronger effects on wing size than the ones produced by Ras2 mutants (Fig. 7A–C; Supple. Fig. 1B), indicating that this pathway can operate in the absence of Ras2 activity. To further explore the possible relationships between Ras2 and InR signalling, we first analysed the ability of activated forms of Ras1 and Ras2 to compensate for a reduction in the activity of the InR. As expected, the overexpression of a dominant negative version of the receptor (InRDN) results in a strong reduction in the level of P-Akt accumulation (Fig. 7D and E and Supple. Fig. 1C). In this genetic background (salEPv-Gal4 UAS-InRDN/UAS-GFP) the introduction of activated forms of Ras1 (salEPv-Gal4 UAS-InRDN/UAS-Ras1V12) and Ras2 (salEPv-Gal4 UAS-InRDN/UAS-Ras2V14) partially rescued the loss of P-Akt (Fig. 7F and G and Supple. Fig. 1C). The expression of activated Ras2 is much more effective that Ras1V12 in the rescue of P-Akt accumulation (the quantifications of relative P-Akt intensity levels are shown in Supple. Fig. 1C). These changes in P-Akt accumulation are also manifest in the resulting adult wings. Thus, expression of InRDN causes a strong reduction in wing size (Fig. 7B, H and Supple. Fig. 1A) that is partially compensated by Ras2V14 (Fig. 7M and Supple. Fig. 1A) but not by Ras1V12 (Fig. 7J). These wings still display the characteristic excess of vein formation caused by Ras1V12 and Ras2V14 expression (Fig. 7I and L, respectively). Knock down of dp110, encoding the catalytic subunit of the insulin pathway effector PI3K, results in wing size reduction (Fig. 7N and Supple. Fig. 1A) that cannot be restored when activated Ras2 is overexpressed (Fig. 7P and Supple. Fig. 1A). Similarly, overexpression of Ras1V12 in the dp110 knock down background is not able to rescue the wing size reduction caused by dp110 loss. Thus, Ras1V12/dp110-RNAi wings are very reduced in size and display a strong phenotype of ectopic vein differentiation (Fig. 7O). These results are compatible with Ras2V14 being more effective than Ras1V12 in rescuing the lost of InR activity.

We used a similar approach to analyse the contribution of Ras1 and Ras2 to EGFR signalling. First, we confirmed that the presence of EGFRDN reduces the accumulation of dP-ERK (Fig. 7R compare with 7Q). In this EGFRDN background, both Ras2V14 (Fig. 7S) and Ras1V12 (Fig. 7T) are able to promote the accumulation of dP-ERK. The corresponding adult phenotypes are consistent with the changes observed in dP-ERK accumulation. Thus both Ras1V12 and Ras2V14 expression is able to promote vein formation in the EGFRDN background (Fig. 7U–W). These results suggest that in the wing epithelia Ras1 would be acting mainly through the Raf/MAPK signalling cascade and both Ras1 and Ras2 would be able to activate this pathway when over-expressed and constitutively activated.

Ras1 can engage in molecular interactions with Raf and Dp110, although it is mostly required to activate Raf (Orme et al., 2006). To analyse the possibility of Ras2 interactions with Raf and Dp110 we did pull-down and immunoprecipitation assays. In pull-down experiments, we translated in vitro Raf and Dp110 and searched for direct interactions with Ras2 and with its activated form Ras2V14. We found that Ras2 and Ras2V14 interact with both Raf and Dp110 (Fig. 8I). The Ras2/Dp110 interaction appears stronger than the Ras2/Raf one (2 vs 0.7% of total Dp110 and Raf found in the pull down assay respectively), and the strength of both interactions increases when we used the Ras2V14 form (4.6% vs 1.5% of total Dp110 and Raf) (Fig. 8I). We also studied the possibility of in vivo interactions between Ras2 and Dp110 by immunoprecipitation using extracts obtained from embryos expressing tagged versions of both proteins (Fig. 8J). We observed Ras2/Dp110 interaction in embryos expressing an activated form of the InR, Ras2 and Dp110 (Fig. 8J) and inconsistently in embryos expressing only Ras2 and Dp110 (data not shown). These results indicate that Ras2 can interact directly or indirectly with Dp110 and Raf, and that Ras2 could be part of a protein complex including Dp110 in vivo.

Ras and Ras-related proteins connect activated transmembrane receptors with different downstream effectors. These proteins share extensive sequence identity, and differ mostly in the C-terminal part of the protein, the HVR, which is involved in the regulation of their subcellular localization (Castellano and Downward, 2011). Murine and human Ras and Ras-related proteins interact with both Raf and PI3K, and both pathways cooperate to regulate cellular growth through the phosphorylation and inactivation of Tsc2 (Inoki et al., 2002; Ma et al., 2005). True Ras and Ras-related proteins have Ras1 and Ras2 as orthologous proteins in Drosophila, respectively, and this facilitates the analysis of their functional requirements and the identification of their downstream targets. In this sense, whereas Ras1 has been thoroughly characterised, there are very few data on Ras2, and no mutants affecting the gene had been identified so far.

We have generated and characterised a set of Ras2 alleles, and find that Ras2 function is not required for Drosophila development or viability. This is in stark contrast to Ras1 mutations, which are embryonic lethal and display alterations in all developmental processes involving the activity of the ERK signalling pathway (Schweitzer and Shilo, 1997; Wassarman et al., 1995). The different behaviour of Ras1 and Ras2 mutations indicates that Ras1 suffices to provide Ras function compatible with the normal activation of their downstream effectors. However, and although Ras2 is not required for organism viability, mutant Ras2 flies show phenotypes affecting organ size and life span. These phenotypes are similar but weaker than those caused by impaired InR signalling (Broughton et al., 2005; Haselton et al., 2010), suggesting that Ras2 might have a role in the generation of physiological levels of InR signalling even in the presence of Ras1. In agreement, we found that Ras2 can interact with the catalytic subunit of PI3K (Dp110), a downstream effector of InR signalling, and that Ras2 mutant flies accumulate lower levels of P-Akt.

The activation of the InR leads to the production of phosphatidylinositol (3,4,5) triphosphate (PIP3) through the kinase activity of the Dp110/p60 PI3K complex (Lizcano and Alessi, 2002). The generation of PIP3 recruits both phosphatidylinositol-dependent kinase 1 (PDK1) and Akt to the membrane. Phosphorylated and activated Akt phosphorylates several effectors including the transcription factor Foxo, which is then retained in the cytoplasm, and the small GTPase activating proteins TSC1/2, leading to the activation of the TORC1 complex and to the promotion of ribosomal biogenesis and protein synthesis (Lizcano and Alessi, 2002). A key aspect of InR signalling is that the receptor can use several complementary mechanisms to activate PI3K, including direct binding of the receptor to the regulatory subunit of PI3K (p60), binding of the receptor to PI3K through the molecular adaptor Chico and recruitment of Ras by the receptor leading to stimulation of PI3K (Castellano and Downward, 2011). Consequently, Ras2 function might be just one among several routes from InR to PI3K, and this might explain why Ras2 mutants are viable and only display weak InR-related phenotypes. In agreement, flies with a mutated PI3K unable to bind Ras proteins (PI3KRBD) are viable, but display phenotypes characteristic of reduced InR signalling (Orme et al., 2006; Prober and Edgar, 2002). PI3KRBD flies show stronger phenotypes than Ras2 mutant flies, and in particular they present a reduction in body size (Orme et al., 2006). The differences between PI3KRBD and Ras2 mutant flies could be explained if Ras1 can partially rescue PI3K activation in Ras2 mutants, but not in PI3KRBD animals.

Our findings related to Drosophila Ras2 are very much compatible with the biochemical characteristics of its closest human orthologous, R-Ras2/TC21. In this manner, knockout mice for TC21, as well as double knockout R-Ras1−/−––; R-Ras2−/−–– mice, are viable in homozygosis (Iborra et al., 2011; Sanz-Rodriguez et al., 2018). In addition, TC21 is implicated in the regulation of growth-promoting pathways, and both Raf and PI3K act as direct effectors required for TC21-induced transformation (Movilla et al., 1999; Rosario et al., 1999, 2001). Specifically, TC21 has also been implicated in the survival and maturation of T cells, and in this system participates upstream of PI3K to provide physiological levels of PI3K activity (Delgado et al., 2009; Iborra et al., 2011). Similarly, TC21 has been described to play a role in oligodendrocyte differentiation through activation of both PI3K/Akt and Raf/MAPK pathways (Sanz-Rodriguez et al., 2018).

The situation observed at normal levels of Ras expression is somewhat altered when these proteins are insensitive to GAP regulation, i.e. constitutively bound to GTP, and overexpressed. In this manner, both activated Ras1 and Ras2 are able to compensate for a loss of EGFR activity, and activated Ras2 can supply Ras function upon a reduction of Ras1 expression. In addition, activated Ras2 more effectively compensates for a reduction in InR activity than activated Ras1, rescuing both the loss of P-Akt and the phenotype caused by InR loss of function. Finally, both Ras1 and Ras2 are able to promote P-Akt accumulation in the wing disc when activated by mutation, but only when these mutant proteins are expressed at high levels. All together, these results suggest that Ras1 and Ras2 retain to some extent the ability to interact with a similar set of effectors, but that at physiological levels of expression Ras1 is necessary and sufficient to implement Raf activation downstream of EGFR and Ras2 is part of one among several possible mechanisms linking InR function to PI3K activation.

We only measured wing size in those cases in which the wing blade is fully extended. In the combinations sal-Gal4 UAS-GFP/UAS Dp110-i and sal-Gal4 UAS-Ras2V14/UAS-Dp110-i is shown the entire wing area (B) Ratio of posterior to anterior compartment size in wings presented in Fig. 7A–C (enGal4 UAS-GFP/ ​+ ​; enGal4/UAS-InRDN and enGal4/UAS-InR*). (C) Average ratio of P-Akt signal intensity between mutant and normal wing blade regions in wing discs of salEPv-Gal4 UAS-GFP/ ​+ ​(wt; see Fig. 6A’); salEPv-Gal4 UAS-GFP/UAS-InR*; see Fig. 6F’), salEPv-Gal4 UAS-GFP/UAS-InRDN (see Fig. 7E), salEPv-Gal4 UAS-GFP/UAS-Akt-RNAi (see Fig. 5H’), and salEPv-Gal4 UAS- InRDN/UAS-Ras2V14 (see Fig. 7F) and salEPv-Gal4 UAS-InRDN/UAS-Ras1V12 (see Fig. 7G).ApplicationApplicationOligonucleotides used and cloning method of UAS-Raf-Myc, UAS-PI3K-Myc, UAS-Flag-Ras1, UAS-Flag-Ras1V12, UAS-Flag-Ras2 and UAS-Flag-Ras2V14.Application
